poem:
The Underbellow's Bloom

"Beware the glumphing Gloombeloo,
The shrieky shand, the snarle!"
My father cried, his face pale blue,
"Lest you get your soul marle!"

I donned my gleefuls, stout and bright,
My borble-blade I bore,
And stepped into the dimming light,
To face the dark before.

The underpass, a cavern vast,
With clang and clunking sound,
A dribble-dribble, falling fast,
Upon the muddied ground.

Then came the Bloor, with eyes agleam,
A snuffling, snorting drone,
He gave a fearsome, gurgly scream,
And made a chilling moan.

My borble-blade, I swung it wide,
A whiz and a wet thwack!
The Bloor recoiled, with wounded pride,
And staggered reeling back.

With clatters, clanks, and hollow roars,
He fled into the gloom,
I'd won the fight, and closed his doors,
Escaped impending doom.

Back home I rushed, with joyful shout,
My tale I did unfold,
The glumphing Gloombeloo is out,
My courage manifold!

So heed my warning, stout and true,
From shrieks and snarls be spared!
The underpass, the glumphing Gloombeloo,
The Bloor, the Bloor it dared!
